questions.question_text:
In a lessons learned report, it is suspected that a well-organized, well-funded, and extremely sophisticated group of attackers may have been responsible for a breach at a nuclear facility.
Which of the following describes the type of actors that may have been implicated?

discussion.content: A.. The Nation State Actor has a 'Licence to Hack'. They work for a government to disrupt or compromise target governments, organisations or individuals to gain access to valuable data or intelligence, and can create incidents that have international significance.
I didn't even read the question... I just saw "nuclear" and went with Nation State haha

gibson page 269... Some attackers are organized and sponsored by a nation state or government. An advanced persistent threat APT is a targeted attack against a network. ( this is basically how it starts in the book. Not much really there )
Yep, that actually happened (stuxnet)
processes hiiiidden is always rootkit
More often than not, one will have to reformat/reimage the drive to get rid of a rootkit.

Yes rootkits
A Rootkit is malware designed to hide itself from Windows and antivirus software. Rootkits are used to monitor network traffic and keystrokes. A Rootkit hides itself inside the operating system. “Rootkits primarily aim at user-mode applications, but they also focus on a computer’s hypervisor, the kernel, or even firmware. Rootkits can completely deactivate or destroy the anti-malware software installed in an infected computer, thus making a rootkit attack difficult to track and eliminate.
The administrator, however, does not see any suspicious process running. Rootkit are able to hide themselves from user and antivirus software.
the machine has been remediated twice ... if you re-deploy it can't be rootkit anymore, but here this seems to be the only answer

comments.content: what about the master boot record rootkit?
Root kit in the MBR would not be eliminated with remediation of the machine.

questions.question_text:
A security administrator is analyzing a user report in which the computer exhibits odd network-related outages. The administrator, however, does not see any suspicious processes running. A prior technician's notes indicate the machine has been remediated twice, but the system still exhibits odd behavior. Files were deleted from the system recently.
Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of this behavior?

choices.C: Implement a filter on the mail gateway that prevents the lead form from being emailed.
choices.D: Create an automated alert on the SIEM for anomalous sales team activity.
choices.B: Install DLP software on the devices used by sales employees.
choices.A: Configure time-of-day restrictions for the sales staff.

questions.question_text:
Joe, a member of the sales team, recently logged into the company servers after midnight local time to download the daily lead form before his coworkers did.
Management has asked the security team to provide a method for detecting this type of behavior without impeding the access for sales employee as they travel overseas.
Which of the following would be the BEST method to achieve this objective?

comments.content: Good point, also time of day restrictions might prevent staff in different time zones accessing the report.

discussion.content: D. They want to "provide a method for detecting this type of behavior" NOT prevent it. Detect not prevent.
Joe is a very versatile person.
SIEM: software actively monitors and reports on data collected by logging tools
Only one options doesn't restrict, which is what they want.
Makes sense, you would want to know who on your team is doing this.

questions.question_text:
A security administrator wants to implement least privilege access for a network share that stores sensitive company data. The organization is particularly concerned with the integrity of data and implementing discretionary access control. The following controls are available:
✑ Read = A user can read the content of an existing file.
✑ Write = A user can modify the content of an existing file and delete an existing file.
✑ Create = A user can create a new file and place data within the file.
A missing control means the user does not have that access. Which of the following configurations provides the appropriate control to support the organization/s requirements?

discussion.content: Owners should be able to Read, Write and Create
B. The "Others" group should not have "Read, Create" - least privileges would demand that Others would not be able to create - just read.

comments.content: So smart person, but you did not know that write permission does not imply read

Whoops - A is best answer. Write permission does not imply read. For example a directory where the user can deposit data (potentially destroying existing data), but not read what others have deposited.
MelvinJohn my man youve been all over the place with your answers.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Agree with Pietervh
I meant for choice A. was definitely correct.
disregard for my choice for B
this was the easiest question so far. I automatically eliminated A, C, and D. Because other must have only (Read)

I will go with A, since all the other options are wrong. Like owner should have all read, write and create it’s like a must for owners and none of the other options comply this. The story is over right there so it’s A
I'm going to say C on this one. It's the only option that doesn't contain 'Write' for Members and Others.

from Gibson to support the provided answers.
All permissions in this operating system fall
within three groups of users: owner, group, and other. The permissions
associated with the owner and the group to which the owner belongs are based
on their roles, but all of those who are not the owner, or a member of the owner’s
group, fall within the category of other.
The permissions for this group are set separately from the other two and, with
very few special exceptions, are a combination of read, write, and execute.
Within this environment, you can create a database and give yourself (owner)
permission to read and write, give other admins (group) only read permission,
and not give any permission to those, not in admin (other).
You could just as easily create a script file that cleans up log files and frees space
on a workstation. To do this, you would give yourself (owner) all rights, give
other admins (group) the ability to read and execute, and give basic users (other)
the right only to execute.

Out of the available choices, I'd have to go with 'C'.

A. Owners: Read, Write, Create Group Members: Read, Write Others: Read, Create
- Data integrity is at risk due to Group Members having Write (aka Edit) permissions.

B. Owners: Write, Create Group Members: Read, Write, Create Others: Read
- Data integrity is at risk due to Group Members having Write (aka Edit) permissions.

D. Owners: Write, Create Group Members: Read, Create Others: Read, Write, Create
- Data integrity is at risk due to Others having Write (aka Edit) permissions.

C. Owners: Read, Write Group Members: Read, Create Others: Read, Create
- Group Members and Others can Read all files and Create new files (making them the owner of those files.
- Owners can Read all file, but are the only ones allowed to Write (aka Edit) files, but only their own.
This is kinda bulls**t. We have a corporate share at work. Only the Owner can Read, Write, and Create. All others can only read. That's the LEAST privileged.

comments.content: CompTIA requirements - as in, they won’t tell you and you have to guess.

discussion.content: I don not understand the question. what is the company requirements .
Only answer which is right is A as Owners will need full access which is Read, Write and Create. Only A shows that the Owners have all these access.
i dont understand this question

comments.content: When working with groups remember that no matter what OS you are working with, if you give a user has full access in one group and deny access in another group, the result is deny access. However, group permissions are cumulative. Therefore, if a user belongs to two groups and one of them has more liberal access, the user will have the more liberal access, except where the deny access permissions is involved. If a user has difficulty accessing information after he or she has been added to a new group, the first item to check for is conflicting permissions.

I used to be a UNIX Sys Admin and I agree that in the real world C is the only choice that would not be complete chaos (picture anyone in your group being able to delete files that you created), but I am leaning towards B. I think they might want B as the answer even though in the real world it would be chaos because they might use the logic that Owners need to at least be able to create new files, Group Members need to at least be able to write and delete files, and Others need to at least be able to read files. Can anybody tell us if any other sources have a different suggested answer for this mornonic question?
A can't be right. I hardly think "lease privilege access" would entail letting Others create files.

discussion.content: C. Owners are part of group so can rw and cr. Group can read and create new, if they create they can then write/del their own (become owner). Users can read and create new, if they create they can write/del their own. This is the only option where the owner has full control of their own. Ideally you would want it so users can only read/create if they are a part of the group.

comments.content: There's no harm in others creating something. The important thing is that they can't write, meaning modify any files or delete them. Who cares if they create something? The group members or owners can just delete them.
Covfefe thanks for this it helped clarify it for me and made me think about it differently
Owners should be able to able to create, read and write their own data. A is the only option which has this so its the better answer

discussion.content: I just wanna know why it's A rather than B. I think others shouldn't create something

choices.B: Owners: Write, Create Group Members: Read, Write, Create Others: Read
choices.D: Owners: Write, Create Group Members: Read, Create Others: Read, Write, Create
choices.C: Owners: Read, Write Group Members: Read, Create Others: Read, Create
choices.A: Owners: Read, Write, Create Group Members: Read, Write Others: Read, Create

discussion.content:
In IP spoofing, a hacker uses tools to modify the source address in the packet header to make the receiving computer system think the packet is from a trusted source, such as another computer on a legitimate network, and accept it. Because this occurs at the network level, there are no external signs of tampering.

This type of attack is common in Denial-of-Service (DoS) attacks, which can overwhelm computer networks with traffic. In a DoS attack, hackers use spoofed IP addresses to overwhelm computer servers with packets of data, shutting them down. Geographically dispersed botnets — networks of compromised computers — are often used to send the packets. Each botnet potentially contains tens of thousands of computers capable of spoofing multiple source IP addresses. As a result, the automated attack is difficult to trace.
looks like there were a lot of open connections that ware performed on a web server. By looking at those choices. the choice C is best.

I think it can't be D because the answer D says that the server is not sending the ACK it, if you look at the server it sent the SYN/ACK , if it said the host hasn't send the ACK then it would have made sense.
Can anyone provide and explanation for this one? My first reaction was to go with D, but now I'm not sure at all.

comments.content: nvm it can't be D, the client would have to send the ACK to the server in order to complete the 3-way handshake.

choices.C: The server is under an IP spoofing resource exhaustion attack.
choices.D: The server is unable to complete the TCP three-way handshake and send the last ACK.
choices.B: The server is compromised, and is attacking multiple hosts on the Internet.
choices.A: The server is under a DDoS attack from multiple geographic locations.
